questions.question: In the voluntary-to-reflexive continuum described, rhythmic movements (e.g., locomotion) are primarily generated by:
options: local spinal or brainstem circuitry (central pattern generators) that organises timing and spatial patterning
continuous conscious monitoring by prefrontal cortex to maintain the rhythm
a single monosynaptic spinal reflex arc repeated without interneuronal circuitry
cerebellar circuits alone generating rhythm without spinal involvement
questions.answer: local spinal or brainstem circuitry (central pattern generators) that organises timing and spatial patterning

questions.question: Curare toxin was used as an example of acetylcholine receptor disruption. Its key effect is to:
options: increase acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, producing sustained contraction
block acetylcholine receptors in muscle tissue, preventing muscle fibres from responding to motor nerve stimulation
destroy myelin on peripheral nerves, producing a progressive sensory loss pattern
selectively enhance dopaminergic signalling in striatum, reducing movement
questions.answer: block acetylcholine receptors in muscle tissue, preventing muscle fibres from responding to motor nerve stimulation

questions.question: Which cluster of signs best matches lower motor neurone syndrome as described?
options: hyperreflexia, spasticity and increased muscle tone
simultanagnosia, optic ataxia and oculomotor apraxia
resting tremor with preserved reflexes and no wasting
paralysis with muscle wasting, loss of reflexes and fasciculation
questions.answer: paralysis with muscle wasting, loss of reflexes and fasciculation

questions.question: According to the sustained movement description, tetanic contractions occur when:
options: single action potentials generate prolonged contractions without summation
high-frequency action potentials arrive rapidly so individual twitches summate into a larger, prolonged contraction
calcium entry is prevented so contraction relies on passive recoil
motor units are recruited in reverse order (large-to-small) to prevent fatigue
questions.answer: high-frequency action potentials arrive rapidly so individual twitches summate into a larger, prolonged contraction

questions.question: In the innervation terminology used, a motor unit refers to:
options: a single muscle fibre and its acetylcholine receptors
one motor neurone together with all muscle fibres it innervates
the corticospinal tract controlling a limb segment
a group of synergistic muscles acting on a joint
questions.answer: one motor neurone together with all muscle fibres it innervates

questions.question: Upper motor neurone signals were described as producing contralateral control primarily because they:
options: cross the midline at the neuromuscular junction
cross the midline at the brainstem before descending to lower motor neurones
cross twice (cortex and spinal cord), yielding ipsilateral control
never cross; contralateral control is due to peripheral nerve decussation
questions.answer: cross the midline at the brainstem before descending to lower motor neurones

questions.question: A patient can understand a command and has no paralysis, but performs a multi-step tool use sequence in an inappropriate order. This pattern most closely matches:
options: ideomotor apraxia
utilisation behaviour
ideational apraxia
alien hand syndrome
questions.answer: ideational apraxia

questions.question: Optic ataxia, as described, is best defined as:
options: an inability to recognise objects despite intact reaching movements
an inability to reach accurately under visual guidance (a visuomotor transformation deficit)
a failure to initiate self-generated movement sequences
a compulsive tendency to imitate observed actions
questions.answer: an inability to reach accurately under visual guidance (a visuomotor transformation deficit)

questions.question: In the dorsal vs ventral stream double dissociation (RV vs DF), which pattern matches the notes?
options: both patients showed intact verbal shape discrimination but impaired grasping
RV was impaired at shape discrimination but grasped normally; DF showed the opposite
RV discriminated object shape but showed inappropriate visually guided grasping; DF performed at chance on shape discrimination yet grasped effectively
RV and DF both showed simultanagnosia due to bilateral parietal damage
questions.answer: RV discriminated object shape but showed inappropriate visually guided grasping; DF performed at chance on shape discrimination yet grasped effectively

questions.question: The functional dissociation between premotor cortex and supplementary motor area (SMA) for sequencing was summarised as:
options: premotor cortex is specialised for uncued learned sequences; SMA is for externally cued actions
SMA is mainly for reflexive responses; premotor cortex for simple spinal reflexes
both are execution-only regions with no role in sequencing
SMA supports linked self-generated (uncued) movement sequences, whereas premotor cortex is more involved in producing cued movements
questions.answer: SMA supports linked self-generated (uncued) movement sequences, whereas premotor cortex is more involved in producing cued movements

questions.question: In the error-correction account of cerebellar function, the cerebellum contributes to smooth movement by:
options: sending motor commands directly to lower motor neurones, bypassing cortex
storing a permanent map of each muscle's resting length and preventing adjustments
inhibiting all sensory feedback during movement to prevent interference
comparing intended motor signals with information about what the body is doing and adjusting output to reduce mismatch
questions.answer: comparing intended motor signals with information about what the body is doing and adjusting output to reduce mismatch

questions.question: A defining feature of ballistic movements (as described) is that they:
options: depend on continuous online sensory feedback to be corrected mid-flight
occur only in the presence of visual cues and conscious control
are generated by a single monosynaptic spinal reflex
occur so rapidly that once initiated they are difficult to modify using sensory feedback
questions.answer: occur so rapidly that once initiated they are difficult to modify using sensory feedback

questions.question: In the examples of cerebellar dysfunction, hypometria refers to:
options: movements overshooting the intended goal due to excessive amplitude
movements falling short of the intended goal
a complete inability to initiate voluntary movement
a loss of semantic knowledge for action sequences
questions.answer: movements falling short of the intended goal

questions.question: Which task was explicitly listed as cerebellum-reliant within field sobriety testing examples?
options: picture naming under time pressure
touching the tip of the nose with eyes closed
recalling a word list after a 15-minute delay
judging facial emotion intensity
questions.answer: touching the tip of the nose with eyes closed

questions.question: In the basal ganglia overview, the central functional emphasis was on:
options: encoding object identity in the ventral stream
inhibition, action selection and initiation (including stopping or altering actions)
primary sensory processing of cutaneous input
generating hippocampal place fields
questions.answer: inhibition, action selection and initiation (including stopping or altering actions)

questions.question: In the direct/indirect pathway summary, hyperkinesia was described as most consistent with:
options: excess direct pathway output or insufficient indirect pathway output
insufficient direct pathway output or excess indirect pathway output
complete loss of thalamocortical drive due to GPi/SNr silence
failure of upper motor neurones to cross the midline at the brainstem
questions.answer: excess direct pathway output or insufficient indirect pathway output

questions.question: Which description best matches the basal ganglia loop disruption attributed to Huntington's disease?
options: progressive dopamine cell loss in SNc producing hypokinesia
primary degeneration of cerebellar Purkinje cells producing intention tremor
excessive inhibition of thalamus due to overactive STN producing bradykinesia
degeneration in striatum (caudate/putamen) reduces inhibitory modulation, yielding hyperkinesia and chorea
questions.answer: degeneration in striatum (caudate/putamen) reduces inhibitory modulation, yielding hyperkinesia and chorea

questions.question: Why was L-DOPA described as preferable to dopamine itself in pharmacological treatment for Parkinson's disease?
options: dopamine cannot cross the blood–brain barrier, whereas L-DOPA can and is converted to dopamine in the brain
L-DOPA directly blocks D2 receptors in striatum, reducing dopamine transmission
dopamine is too stable to be metabolised, whereas L-DOPA is rapidly broken down
L-DOPA selectively increases serotonin but not dopamine, avoiding motor side effects
questions.answer: dopamine cannot cross the blood–brain barrier, whereas L-DOPA can and is converted to dopamine in the brain

questions.question: The DBS/lesion rationale targeting STN or GPi in Parkinson's disease was described as:
options: increasing abnormal inhibitory output from GPi to suppress tremor
reducing abnormal and excessive inhibitory output from the internal pallidal segment, improving downstream thalamocortical drive
restoring hippocampal LTP by stimulating NMDA receptors
preventing dopamine synthesis in striatum to reduce dyskinesias
questions.answer: reducing abnormal and excessive inhibitory output from the internal pallidal segment, improving downstream thalamocortical drive

questions.question: In the basal ganglia pathway account, dopamine depletion was said to hinder movement initiation primarily because dopamine normally:
options: facilitates movement by modulating striatal activity so indirect-pathway inhibition is reduced and direct-pathway facilitation is supported
blocks glutamate release in motor cortex, preventing action potentials
increases acetylcholine receptor density at the neuromuscular junction
inhibits cerebellar error correction, making movements ballistic
questions.answer: facilitates movement by modulating striatal activity so indirect-pathway inhibition is reduced and direct-pathway facilitation is supported

questions.question: According to the list attributed to Norman and Shallice, executive control is recruited in all of the following situations except:
options: planning multi-step behaviour
overcoming a habitual response
executing a simple spinal reflex such as the knee-jerk
dealing with danger or difficulty
questions.answer: executing a simple spinal reflex such as the knee-jerk

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the four inhibition functions listed for DLPFC-mediated control?
options: restraining potentiated behaviour
preventing information from interfering with processing
removing irrelevant information from working memory
generating novel goals for action in order to create new behavioural rules
questions.answer: generating novel goals for action in order to create new behavioural rules

questions.question: In the examples of executive control, the oddball task was used primarily to probe:
options: motor learning in the cerebellum
reward prediction learning in the basal ganglia
initiation and selection of desired behaviours under attention demands
place-cell remapping in the hippocampus
questions.answer: initiation and selection of desired behaviours under attention demands

questions.question: A stroke damaging medial PFC circuitry (with basal ganglia/thalamus/ACC involvement) producing lethargy, slowed action and poor sustained goal-directed behaviour was termed:
options: utilisation behaviour
simultanagnosia
aboulia
prosopagnosia
questions.answer: aboulia

questions.question: Alien hand syndrome (as described) is most strongly associated with:
options: unilateral occipital lesions that remove visual input to cortex
amygdala hyperactivity producing exaggerated fear responses
damage confined to the hippocampus producing dense amnesia
damage involving frontal cortex and, in some cases, corpus callosum, producing seemingly autonomous hand actions
questions.answer: damage involving frontal cortex and, in some cases, corpus callosum, producing seemingly autonomous hand actions

questions.question: In the study where participants imagined familiar or unfamiliar person-location combinations, vmPFC activation increased with:
options: novelty of the combination
greater perceptual complexity of the imagined scene
familiarity of the imagined combination
higher levels of immediate sensory stimulation from the environment
questions.answer: familiarity of the imagined combination

questions.question: Diminishing marginal utility (as invoked in expected utility discussions) implies that:
options: each additional unit of reward yields a progressively smaller increment in subjective value
subjective value increases linearly with objective value across all magnitudes
low-probability outcomes are ignored regardless of framing
expected utility and expected value are identical for all decision contexts
questions.answer: each additional unit of reward yields a progressively smaller increment in subjective value

questions.question: Which pattern is consistent with the mapping of loss aversion described under prospect theory?
options: risk seeking for high-probability gains and risk aversion for high-probability losses
risk aversion for low-probability gains and risk seeking for low-probability losses
risk seeking for high-probability gains and risk aversion for low-probability losses
risk aversion for high-probability gains and risk seeking for high-probability losses
questions.answer: risk aversion for high-probability gains and risk seeking for high-probability losses

questions.question: After highly publicised plane-crash reports, a person judges flying as more dangerous than driving largely because crash examples are easy to recall. This most closely illustrates:
options: representativeness heuristic
anchoring and adjustment bias
expected utility maximisation
availability heuristic
questions.answer: availability heuristic

questions.question: Classifying an individual as belonging to a category based on similarity to a stereotype, while neglecting base-rate information, most closely reflects:
options: availability heuristic
anchoring and adjustment bias
representativeness heuristic
bounded rationality
questions.answer: representativeness heuristic

questions.question: In the anchoring-and-adjustment account described, the central error is that people:
options: ignore any initial value and respond purely randomly
always correct fully away from the anchor to the true value
use base rates to compute exact probabilities before responding
begin from an implicit or explicit anchor and make insufficient adjustments away from it
questions.answer: begin from an implicit or explicit anchor and make insufficient adjustments away from it

questions.question: A Nash equilibrium was defined (in the notes) as:
options: a strategy that maximises joint payoff regardless of the other player
a strategy that always involves mutual cooperation
a set of strategies such that no player has an incentive to change given what the other players are doing
a rule that can be broken if doing so increases expected value
questions.answer: a set of strategies such that no player has an incentive to change given what the other players are doing

questions.question: A secondary reinforcer, as defined in the reward section, is best described as:
options: a reward that directly benefits survival (e.g., water or food)
a punishment that reduces negative outcomes
a reward that has value because it can be used to obtain other rewards
a reinforcer that only exists during sleep
questions.answer: a reward that has value because it can be used to obtain other rewards

questions.question: In the simplified account of addiction included in the decision-making notes, addiction was linked to:
options: inhibition of opioid receptors and reduced tolerance
exclusive activation of GABA receptors with no dopamine involvement
overstimulation of opioid receptors and increased tolerance
NMDA receptor blockade leading to reduced synaptic consolidation
questions.answer: overstimulation of opioid receptors and increased tolerance

questions.question: In the mobile gaming section, the relationship between adolescent loot box spending and problem gambling was described as:
options: problem gambling causes loot box spending, but loot box spending does not influence gambling
loot box spending causes problem gambling, but gambling does not predict loot box spending
a bidirectional relationship in which problem gambling and loot box spending can each increase the other
no relationship once socioeconomic status is controlled
questions.answer: a bidirectional relationship in which problem gambling and loot box spending can each increase the other

questions.question: H.M.'s severe anterograde episodic impairment alongside preserved skill learning was used to support which broad memory division?
options: declarative versus non-declarative memory systems
episodic versus short-term memory systems
semantic versus working memory systems
procedural versus sensory memory systems
questions.answer: declarative versus non-declarative memory systems

questions.question: A patient does not remember meeting a doctor but refuses to shake his hand after being pricked during a handshake the previous day. This most directly illustrates preserved:
options: episodic recollection supported by hippocampus
semantic memory supported by anterior temporal lobe
working memory rehearsal supported by DLPFC
classical conditioning/implicit learning despite amnesia
questions.answer: classical conditioning/implicit learning despite amnesia

questions.question: Improved word-stem completion for previously encountered words (despite claiming no memory for the study list) was used to illustrate preserved:
options: episodic recollection with mental time travel
source memory discrimination between contexts
systems consolidation into neocortex
priming as a form of implicit memory
questions.answer: priming as a form of implicit memory

questions.question: Relational theory, as described for hippocampal function, most directly emphasises the hippocampus as:
options: a store of semantic facts that does not interact with cortical systems
a system that forms associations between items and contexts (e.g., what and where), beyond single-item familiarity
a purely motor sequencing structure required for gait
a region specialised only for pain and interoceptive awareness
questions.answer: a system that forms associations between items and contexts (e.g., what and where), beyond single-item familiarity

questions.question: Place cells were described as:
options: CA1 neurons that become active when the animal is in a particular location (a place field)
VLPFC neurons that activate when resolving semantic competition
amygdala neurons that respond only to fearful stimuli
TRN neurons that generate sleep spindles
questions.answer: CA1 neurons that become active when the animal is in a particular location (a place field)

questions.question: In human single-neuron recordings during epilepsy surgery described, place-responsive neurons were reported across which set of regions?
options: hippocampus only
occipital cortex only
thalamus and cerebellum only
hippocampus, parahippocampal cortex, amygdala and frontal cortex
questions.answer: hippocampus, parahippocampal cortex, amygdala and frontal cortex

questions.question: In the transitive inference task described, hippocampal lesions were interpreted as producing a deficit because animals could:
options: not learn any individual pair associations at all
learn only spatial associations but not item associations
learn individual premise associations but fail to infer relations among them when required
show enhanced inference by relying on semantic memory
questions.answer: learn individual premise associations but fail to infer relations among them when required

questions.question: Which description best matches semantic dementia as summarised?
options: a selective deficit in working memory with intact conceptual knowledge
a progressive breakdown of conceptual knowledge across modalities (often from specific to more general), with prominent word/object understanding deficits
a selective deficit in episodic encoding caused by bilateral hippocampal resection
a disorder defined primarily by confabulation due to isolated prefrontal lesions
questions.answer: a progressive breakdown of conceptual knowledge across modalities (often from specific to more general), with prominent word/object understanding deficits

questions.question: In complementary learning systems, the hippocampus and neocortex were contrasted such that:
options: hippocampus learns slowly to avoid interference; neocortex learns rapidly to separate similar episodes
hippocampus stores only semantic concepts; neocortex stores only episodic traces
hippocampus supports fast binding and separation of episodes; neocortex supports slower learning of shared structure to avoid catastrophic interference
both systems have identical learning rates but different neurotransmitters
questions.answer: hippocampus supports fast binding and separation of episodes; neocortex supports slower learning of shared structure to avoid catastrophic interference

questions.question: Which pairing matches the consolidation timescales described (systems vs synaptic consolidation)?
options: systems consolidation: about 1 hour; synaptic consolidation: about 28 days
systems consolidation: about 1 hour; synaptic consolidation: several years
systems consolidation: occurs only during REM; synaptic consolidation: occurs only during N1
systems consolidation: hippocampus time-limited role over weeks; synaptic consolidation: protein-synthesis-dependent changes vulnerable over about an hour
questions.answer: systems consolidation: hippocampus time-limited role over weeks; synaptic consolidation: protein-synthesis-dependent changes vulnerable over about an hour

questions.question: In the study where slow-wave rhythm was enhanced by stimulation during sleep, the reported outcome pattern was that:
options: declarative and skill memory improved equally
skill memory improved but declarative memory did not
stimulation decreased slow-wave sleep and impaired learning
verbal (declarative) learning improved while skill memory was unchanged
questions.answer: verbal (declarative) learning improved while skill memory was unchanged

questions.question: In the infant word-learning nap study described, the key finding was that napping after learning was associated with:
options: better generalisation of word meaning beyond the learned exemplar, correlated with sleep-related activity (spindles)
worse generalisation due to interference from sleep replay
no difference in generalisation because sleep has only passive protective effects
improved procedural motor performance but unchanged word comprehension
questions.answer: better generalisation of word meaning beyond the learned exemplar, correlated with sleep-related activity (spindles)

questions.question: In the human reactivation study described (card-location learning paired with odours/sounds), which pattern was reported?
options: cueing during wake improved memory more than cueing during sleep
cueing during sleep impaired memory relative to no cue
cueing effects were identical in sleep and wake conditions
odour cue re-presentation during sleep improved memory, whereas in the wake condition the cue could worsen memory
questions.answer: odour cue re-presentation during sleep improved memory, whereas in the wake condition the cue could worsen memory

questions.question: Retrieval-induced forgetting (RIF) was interpreted as arising because retrieval practice:
options: strengthens the practised item while suppressing competing related memories, reducing later accessibility of the competitors
causes uniform forgetting across all category members regardless of practice
prevents any future interference by permanently deleting all similar memories
only affects semantic memory and cannot influence episodic associations
questions.answer: strengthens the practised item while suppressing competing related memories, reducing later accessibility of the competitors

questions.question: In think/no-think style findings described for PTSD, compared with trauma-exposed controls, PTSD patients typically showed:
options: better suppression and reduced memory for suppressed items
worse suppression, indexed by relatively better memory for items they attempted to suppress
no difference in suppression but increased semantic memory accuracy
improved suppression only when sleep-deprived
questions.answer: worse suppression, indexed by relatively better memory for items they attempted to suppress

questions.question: The right-hemisphere predominance account of hemispatial neglect described explains right-parietal lesions producing left neglect because:
options: the right hemisphere can represent both sides of space, whereas the left hemisphere is more limited to the right side
the left hemisphere exclusively controls eye movements for both visual fields
left visual cortex is absent in most people, making right lesions uniquely damaging
neglect results from primary visual cortex blindness rather than attentional control
questions.answer: the right hemisphere can represent both sides of space, whereas the left hemisphere is more limited to the right side

questions.question: A key observation used to argue that neglect is not a primary visual cortex disorder is that neglect patients:
options: show complete blindness in the contralesional field under all circumstances
can attend to left-sided information when it is explicitly pointed out to them
show a selective inability to recognise object identity (agnosia) with preserved spatial attention
only fail on auditory localisation tasks, not visual tasks
questions.answer: can attend to left-sided information when it is explicitly pointed out to them

questions.question: Neglect was described as extending beyond vision in that some patients:
options: show improved sound localisation on the contralesional side compared with controls
only misperceive sounds as more contralesional than they really are
show no auditory effects because neglect is exclusively visual
may respond to contralesional sounds as if they originated from the ipsilesional side and show poorer contralesional auditory localisation
questions.answer: may respond to contralesional sounds as if they originated from the ipsilesional side and show poorer contralesional auditory localisation

questions.question: Balint's syndrome was described as typically resulting from:
options: unilateral temporal lobe damage affecting object recognition
bilateral parietal and occipital damage affecting object-based attention
right inferior parietal lobule atypicality affecting magnitude processing
bilateral hippocampal lesions affecting episodic binding
questions.answer: bilateral parietal and occipital damage affecting object-based attention

questions.question: Simultanagnosia (as described within Balint's syndrome) is best characterised as:
options: a selective deficit in recognising faces
an inability to attend to more than one object at a time regardless of where objects are presented
a selective deficit in visually guided reaching with intact perception
a difficulty making purposeful eye movements without moving the head
questions.answer: an inability to attend to more than one object at a time regardless of where objects are presented

questions.question: In the dyscalculia summary, neuroimaging work suggested the core deficit is localised primarily in:
options: left inferior frontal gyrus
right inferior parietal lobule
bilateral amygdala
posterior cingulate cortex
questions.answer: right inferior parietal lobule

questions.question: ATOM (A Theory of Magnitude) was used to explain why dyscalculia can involve time, speed and distance problems by proposing that these domains share:
options: a common phonological code in left temporal cortex
a single episodic memory store in hippocampus
a common magnitude-processing system spanning time, space and number
a reward-learning mechanism in nucleus accumbens
questions.answer: a common magnitude-processing system spanning time, space and number

questions.question: In Siegle et al.'s fMRI study described (digit sorting vs rating word personal relevance), the depression group showed:
options: decreased amygdala responses to negative words and increased DLPFC across both tasks
increased amygdala activity for negative words and decreased DLPFC activity across tasks
no differences in limbic or prefrontal activity relative to controls
increased NAcc sustained activity during amplification of positive emotion
questions.answer: increased amygdala activity for negative words and decreased DLPFC activity across tasks

questions.question: In the monoamine theory account described, SSRIs were characterised as acting by:
options: blocking dopamine reuptake in the striatum
preventing cortisol release from the adrenal glands
blocking serotonin reuptake so serotonin remains available in the synaptic cleft longer
increasing NMDA receptor opening by removing magnesium blocks
questions.answer: blocking serotonin reuptake so serotonin remains available in the synaptic cleft longer

questions.question: Which statement best matches the STAR*D summary provided in the notes?
options: Remission was achieved primarily at Level 4, with earlier levels rarely effective
CBT was described as ineffective at every level compared to medication
Remission rates increased with each successive treatment level as side effects decreased
Across levels, about 70% of completers showed remission, with remission decreasing and withdrawal increasing at later levels
questions.answer: Across levels, about 70% of completers showed remission, with remission decreasing and withdrawal increasing at later levels

questions.question: In the 5-HTT gene by stress framework described, which account best captures the key interaction?
options: The short allele guarantees depression regardless of life events
Stressful life events alone fully determine later depression risk independent of genotype
The long allele is uniquely harmful only in low-stress environments
The short/short genotype increases risk primarily when combined with early stressful life events; genotype alone is not sufficient
questions.answer: The short/short genotype increases risk primarily when combined with early stressful life events; genotype alone is not sufficient

questions.question: Pezawas et al.'s imaging findings (as described) for the 5-HTT short/short variant included:
options: increased amygdala grey matter volume and strengthened amygdala–cingulate connectivity during fear
selective hippocampal enlargement with no limbic effects
a complete absence of structural differences but enhanced task performance
reduced volume in amygdala and perigenual cingulate with impaired connectivity between them during fearful stimulus processing
questions.answer: reduced volume in amygdala and perigenual cingulate with impaired connectivity between them during fearful stimulus processing

questions.question: In the SSRI response study described (genotype groups split by 5-HTT), which group showed the poorest response to treatment?
options: l/l genotype
s/s genotype
s/l genotype
no genotype differences were reported
questions.answer: s/s genotype

questions.question: According to the Etkin and Wager meta-analysis summary, PTSD showed a pattern of disorder-specific hypoactivity in:
options: occipital cortex and primary motor cortex
prefrontal cortex, thalamus and cingulate regions
hippocampus and amygdala only
posterior insula and cerebellum
questions.answer: prefrontal cortex, thalamus and cingulate regions

questions.question: In the identical twin study described for PTSD risk, the key inference about hippocampal volume was that:
options: hippocampal volume reductions occur only after trauma exposure and only in the combat twin
hippocampal volume predicted PTSD severity in both the combat twin and the non-combat twin, implying a pre-existing risk factor
hippocampal volume was larger in PTSD and this increase predicted resilience
hippocampal volume differences were fully explained by medication use
questions.answer: hippocampal volume predicted PTSD severity in both the combat twin and the non-combat twin, implying a pre-existing risk factor

questions.question: In the typical sleep-stage breakdown given, which stage occupies the largest proportion of total sleep time?
options: N2 (about 45%)
N1 (about 5%)
N3 (about 25%)
REM (about 25%)
questions.answer: N2 (about 45%)

questions.question: Across the sleep-related anxiety findings described, which combined pattern was reported following sleep deprivation?
options: reduced anxiety with decreased amygdala activity and increased PFC activity to negative images
no changes in anxiety or limbic-prefrontal activity
improved suppression in think/no-think tasks due to increased DLPFC engagement
elevated anxiety with greater amygdala activity and reduced PFC activity when viewing negative images
questions.answer: elevated anxiety with greater amygdala activity and reduced PFC activity when viewing negative images

questions.question: In the fear extinction paradigm described, PTSD patients differed from trauma-exposed controls primarily because they:
options: showed normal fear acquisition and extinction learning but impaired extinction recall 24 hours later with reduced vmPFC and hippocampal activity
failed to acquire fear conditioning in the first place
could not learn extinction within-session but showed perfect extinction recall the next day
showed enhanced vmPFC activity during extinction recall compared with controls
questions.answer: showed normal fear acquisition and extinction learning but impaired extinction recall 24 hours later with reduced vmPFC and hippocampal activity

questions.question: EMDR (as described) is best characterised as:
options: a pharmacological intervention that blocks noradrenaline receptors during sleep
a therapy in which patients track a rapidly moving stimulus with their eyes while holding traumatic material in mind
a form of rTMS delivered to posterior parietal cortex to restore attention
a behavioural extinction-only procedure with no memory component
questions.answer: a therapy in which patients track a rapidly moving stimulus with their eyes while holding traumatic material in mind

questions.question: Typical (first-generation) antipsychotics were described as reducing positive symptoms primarily by:
options: blocking D2 dopamine receptors on postsynaptic neurons
increasing serotonin reuptake in raphe projections
enhancing glutamate transmission in cortex
stimulating hippocampal neurogenesis via BDNF
questions.answer: blocking D2 dopamine receptors on postsynaptic neurons

questions.question: Which statement was not listed as a limitation of the dopamine hypothesis (as summarised in the schizophrenia notes)?
options: dopamine abnormalities are not uniform across the brain
the hypothesis does not account well for negative symptoms and typical antipsychotics do not treat them effectively
the dopamine hypothesis fully explains negative symptoms, making additional neurotransmitter accounts unnecessary
typical antipsychotics carry risks such as extrapyramidal side effects
questions.answer: the dopamine hypothesis fully explains negative symptoms, making additional neurotransmitter accounts unnecessary

questions.question: Which account best matches the additional glutamate-based mechanism proposed in the schizophrenia lecture notes?
options: glutamate is elevated everywhere and directly suppresses dopamine synthesis
blocking glutamate transmission eliminates hallucinations and is the standard treatment
GABA levels are elevated and drive excessive cortical inhibition, producing cognitive deficits
drugs that block glutamate transmission can induce psychosis-like symptoms; low glutamate and GABA may reduce inhibition and indirectly contribute to dopamine dysregulation
questions.answer: drugs that block glutamate transmission can induce psychosis-like symptoms; low glutamate and GABA may reduce inhibition and indirectly contribute to dopamine dysregulation

questions.question: Atypical antipsychotics were described as differing from typical antipsychotics primarily because they:
options: block only serotonin receptors and not dopamine receptors
act only on glutamate receptors in hippocampus
block both dopamine and serotonin receptors (including 5HT2A), with greater impact on negative symptoms
increase dopamine transmission uniformly across cortex and striatum
questions.answer: block both dopamine and serotonin receptors (including 5HT2A), with greater impact on negative symptoms

questions.question: In the reality monitoring framework described, the key cognitive judgement is whether information was:
options: encoded in REM sleep versus NREM sleep
learned through reinforcement versus punishment
internally generated versus externally perceived
retrieved from semantic memory versus episodic memory
questions.answer: internally generated versus externally perceived

questions.question: In the schizophrenia reality-monitoring findings described, the specific impairment was most consistently linked to:
options: recognising externally presented items but not imagined items
enhanced recollection for self-generated items
misattributing self-generated items, alongside reduced activation in anterior prefrontal cortex during reality monitoring
damage restricted to occipital cortex during visual perception
questions.answer: misattributing self-generated items, alongside reduced activation in anterior prefrontal cortex during reality monitoring

questions.question: In the cognitive training intervention described for schizophrenia, improved reality monitoring was associated with:
options: reduced anterior PFC activity due to efficiency gains
a selective decrease in hippocampal volume
improvement after about 80 hours of training that correlated with increased anterior PFC activity
worsened performance due to increased distraction
questions.answer: improvement after about 80 hours of training that correlated with increased anterior PFC activity

questions.question: In the sleep spindle findings described for schizophrenia, sleep spindles were reported to correlate with:
options: poorer overnight memory consolidation and lower cognitive ability
increased psychotic-like experiences in healthy controls only
fewer spindles being associated with poorer consolidation and lower cognitive ability, and spindles showing negative associations with psychotic-like experiences
spindle count having no relationship with cognition or memory
questions.answer: fewer spindles being associated with poorer consolidation and lower cognitive ability, and spindles showing negative associations with psychotic-like experiences

questions.question: Baran et al.'s thalamocortical findings in schizophrenia (as summarised) were that patients showed:
options: hyperconnectivity between thalamus and cortex that correlated with fewer sleep spindles
hypoconnectivity between thalamus and cortex that correlated with more sleep spindles
no differences in thalamocortical connectivity relative to controls
connectivity differences only during REM sleep with unchanged spindles
questions.answer: hyperconnectivity between thalamus and cortex that correlated with fewer sleep spindles

questions.question: Which mapping between interoception constructs and measurement approaches matches the framework described?
options: questionnaires measure accuracy; heartbeat tasks measure sensibility; awareness is physiological only
awareness is measured only by fMRI; accuracy only by questionnaires
sensibility is objective and accuracy is subjective by definition
questionnaires primarily capture sensibility; heartbeat tasks index accuracy; awareness reflects correspondence between subjective confidence and objective accuracy
questions.answer: questionnaires primarily capture sensibility; heartbeat tasks index accuracy; awareness reflects correspondence between subjective confidence and objective accuracy

questions.question: Which sequence best matches the interoceptive afferent pathway trajectory described?
options: retina to lateral geniculate nucleus to occipital cortex to temporal lobe
motor cortex to brainstem to spinal cord to muscle
amygdala to vmPFC to nucleus accumbens to thalamus
small-diameter afferents to lamina I dorsal horn to contralateral lateral spinothalamic tract to brainstem to thalamus/hypothalamus/amygdala to insula and anterior cingulate
questions.answer: small-diameter afferents to lamina I dorsal horn to contralateral lateral spinothalamic tract to brainstem to thalamus/hypothalamus/amygdala to insula and anterior cingulate

questions.question: In the heartbeat-evoked potential (HEP) work described, which relationship was reported between HEP and behavioural heartbeat perception?
options: HEP magnitude was smaller in good perceivers and unrelated to accuracy
HEP was measurable only during sleep and not during wakefulness
HEP magnitude was larger in good perceivers and positively correlated with heartbeat detection accuracy
HEP magnitude depended only on visual attention and not on cardiac signals
questions.answer: HEP magnitude was larger in good perceivers and positively correlated with heartbeat detection accuracy

questions.question: In Critchley et al.'s heartbeat attention paradigm described, which pattern was reported?
options: posterior cingulate activity tracked heartbeat accuracy and anxiety
hippocampal activity was the strongest correlate of heartbeat accuracy
occipital cortex grey matter volume predicted interoceptive sensibility
anterior insula activity (and insula grey matter) correlated with heartbeat detection accuracy and anxiety/interoceptive reports
questions.answer: anterior insula activity (and insula grey matter) correlated with heartbeat detection accuracy and anxiety/interoceptive reports

questions.question: Within interoceptive predictive processing, a prior was defined as:
options: a purely peripheral baroreceptor discharge pattern
a motor programme stored in SMA
a belief or expectation that shapes predicted body state
a synaptic consolidation mechanism dependent on protein synthesis
questions.answer: a belief or expectation that shapes predicted body state

questions.question: In the panic disorder account described (Pauli et al.), the core vicious cycle was characterised by:
options: greater objective heart rate variability preceding perceptions, which directly caused anxiety independent of interpretation
lower anxiety ratings despite large perceived cardiac changes, preventing physiological escalation
higher anxiety about perceived cardiac changes that contributed to subsequent increases/shortening between heartbeats
absence of cardiac perceptions altogether, with panic arising only from external cues
questions.answer: higher anxiety about perceived cardiac changes that contributed to subsequent increases/shortening between heartbeats

questions.question: The Eating Disorder Inventory interoceptive deficits subscale (as described) is primarily intended to capture:
options: objective heartbeat counting accuracy compared to ECG
a direct measure of sleep spindle density
a lack of confidence in recognising and identifying emotions and sensations of hunger/satiety (confusion and mistrust of bodily signals)
accuracy of distance estimation in numerical magnitude tasks
questions.answer: a lack of confidence in recognising and identifying emotions and sensations of hunger/satiety (confusion and mistrust of bodily signals)

questions.question: In Kerr et al.'s interoceptive attention findings for weight-restored anorexia nervosa described, the pattern most central to symptom links was:
options: increased posterior insula activity specifically during bladder interoception
selective hippocampal activation during heart interoception only
reduced dorsal mid-insula activity during stomach interoception with associations to anxiety/psychopathology and altered rumination-related engagement
complete normalisation of insula activity during all interoceptive focus conditions
questions.answer: reduced dorsal mid-insula activity during stomach interoception with associations to anxiety/psychopathology and altered rumination-related engagement

questions.question: Which pairing correctly matches the restrictive versus inclusive definitions of interoception discussed?
options: restrictive: purely visceral internal-organ state; inclusive: broader homeostatic sensory capacity including signals like pain/temperature/touch
restrictive: includes all exteroceptive senses; inclusive: excludes all bodily signals
restrictive: only cortical predictions; inclusive: only spinal reflexes
restrictive: mood and personality; inclusive: language comprehension
questions.answer: restrictive: purely visceral internal-organ state; inclusive: broader homeostatic sensory capacity including signals like pain/temperature/touch

questions.question: C-tactile (C) afferents in the interoception notes were described as:
options: large-diameter, heavily myelinated fibres optimised for rapid reflexes
dopaminergic projection fibres from VTA to cortex
the primary output pathway of the cerebellum to motor cortex
unmyelinated fibres associated with affective touch, linked to insula activity and pleasant sensation
questions.answer: unmyelinated fibres associated with affective touch, linked to insula activity and pleasant sensation

questions.question: In the heartbeat-timing studies described, which peripheral receptors were highlighted as conveying information about the timing/strength of each heartbeat and supporting blood-pressure modulation?
options: nociceptors
thermoreceptors
osmoreceptors
baroreceptors
questions.answer: baroreceptors

questions.question: The insular cortex was described as being divided into anterior and posterior parts primarily by:
options: the corpus callosum
the central insular sulcus
the lateral spinothalamic tract
the superior temporal sulcus
questions.answer: the central insular sulcus

questions.question: The term insula (as described) refers to an "island" of cortex that is:
options: hidden beneath the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) under the opercula of frontal/parietal/temporal lobes
located on the dorsal surface of occipital cortex
the outermost layer of primary motor cortex
a nucleus within the thalamus responsible for sleep spindles
questions.answer: hidden beneath the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) under the opercula of frontal/parietal/temporal lobes

questions.question: Which statement best matches the way MDD diagnosis was described in the notes?
options: Diagnosis is determined by a single biomarker test based on cortisol levels
Diagnosis is made only when a patient shows anhedonia and insomnia, regardless of other symptoms
Diagnosis requires only one symptom if it persists for two weeks
Diagnosis requires 5 or more listed symptoms and remains a clinician judgement call; each symptom reflects complex multi-area brain involvement
questions.answer: Diagnosis requires 5 or more listed symptoms and remains a clinician judgement call; each symptom reflects complex multi-area brain involvement

questions.question: In the neurotrophic hypothesis of depression as described, decreased BDNF in hippocampus was linked to:
options: enhanced NMDA-dependent LTP and stronger encoding
a purely peripheral endocrine change with no neural consequences
impaired memory encoding and reduced neuroplastic support for neurons/synapses
a selective increase in semantic memory only
questions.answer: impaired memory encoding and reduced neuroplastic support for neurons/synapses

questions.question: Anhedonia in depression was argued to relate most directly to disruption in which network?
options: dorsal visual stream (parietal) network
fronto-striatal reward circuitry (including striatal structures such as nucleus accumbens)
primary auditory cortex and superior temporal gyrus network
corticospinal motor output pathways only
questions.answer: fronto-striatal reward circuitry (including striatal structures such as nucleus accumbens)

questions.question: In the monoamine overview, serotonin was described as being released to forebrain networks primarily from:
options: ventral tegmental area
locus coeruleus
dorsal raphe
thalamic reticular nucleus
questions.answer: dorsal raphe

questions.question: Polygenic risk scores for MDD (as described) are produced by:
options: estimating hippocampal volume and converting it to a risk percentile
measuring cortisol at baseline and applying a fixed diagnostic cutoff
selecting a single depression gene and testing whether it is present
using GWAS-identified variants to compare an individual's DNA profile to a polygenic roadmap and estimating likelihood of depression (and related covariation)
questions.answer: using GWAS-identified variants to compare an individual's DNA profile to a polygenic roadmap and estimating likelihood of depression (and related covariation)

questions.question: The continuum hypothesis for psychosis described in the schizophrenia lecture notes states that:
options: psychotic experiences occur only in schizophrenia and never in the general population
psychotic experiences reflect a single categorical disorder boundary with no variability
psychosis is purely a consequence of sleep deprivation and disappears with normal sleep
psychotic experiences exist on a spectrum and can occur in non-clinical populations, differing in severity and functional impact
questions.answer: psychotic experiences exist on a spectrum and can occur in non-clinical populations, differing in severity and functional impact

questions.question: Reality monitoring errors were defined (in the notes) as:
options: misidentifying internally generated events (thoughts, dreams, imagined actions) as externally generated events
failing to learn paired associates after a delay
overestimating the frequency of vivid events due to the availability heuristic
confusing magnitude processing with object recognition
questions.answer: misidentifying internally generated events (thoughts, dreams, imagined actions) as externally generated events

questions.question: Sleep spindles were described as a potential treatment target for cognitive deficits in schizophrenia; approaches mentioned included:
options: lesioning hippocampus to force systems consolidation
SSRI augmentation to increase REM density
increasing cortisol to strengthen consolidation
pharmacological and acoustic approaches to boost spindles, with initial healthy-participant trials showing memory consolidation benefits
questions.answer: pharmacological and acoustic approaches to boost spindles, with initial healthy-participant trials showing memory consolidation benefits

questions.question: In the interoception measurement discussion, the MAIA questionnaire was described as primarily capturing:
options: interoceptive sensibility (subjective experience/interpretation of bodily signals)
interoceptive accuracy measured against an objective physiological index
interoceptive awareness as a metacognitive correspondence score by default
heartbeat-evoked potentials directly from EEG
questions.answer: interoceptive sensibility (subjective experience/interpretation of bodily signals)

questions.question: A treatment approach mentioned for Balint's syndrome (noted as having limited evidence and often only single-case success) included:
options: systematic dopamine replacement with L-DOPA
visuoperceptual retraining (e.g., eye-movement training, convergence exercises, and word-reading scanning practice)
sleep spindle acoustic stimulation to restore thalamocortical gating
SSRI treatment to normalise fronto-striatal reward processing
questions.answer: visuoperceptual retraining (e.g., eye-movement training, convergence exercises, and word-reading scanning practice)
